# Goldendoodle

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Goldendoodle [![Golden Doodle Standing
\(HD\).jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Golden_Doodle_Standing_%28HD%29.jpg/220px-
Golden_Doodle_Standing_%28HD%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Golden_Doodle_Standing_\(HD\).jpg)  
---  
Common nicknames | Doodle  
Origin | Canada/U.S.A  
Breed status | Not recognized as a [standardized breed](/wiki/Breed_standard "Breed standard") by any major [kennel club](/wiki/Kennel_club "Kennel club").  
| [hide]Traits  
---  
Weight | Male | 45-100 lbs  
| Female | 45-100 lbs  
Height | Male | 24-26 inches  
| Female | 22-23 inches  
Coat | Wavy, straight, curly  
Color | Cream, Gold, Red, Black, Brown, White  
Litter size | 3-8 puppies  
Life span | 10-15 years  
[Domestic dog](/wiki/Dog "Dog") (_Canis lupus familiaris_)  
  
The **Goldendoodle** is a [cross-breed](/wiki/Dog_crossbreed "Dog crossbreed")
dog, which is obtained by breeding a [Golden Retriever](/wiki/Golden_Retriever
"Golden Retriever") with a [Poodle](/wiki/Poodle "Poodle"). The name, which
alters "poodle" to "doodle" by analogy to "[Labradoodle](/wiki/Labradoodle
"Labradoodle")", was coined in 1992.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 History
  * 2 Appearance
    * 2.1 Shedding
    * 2.2 Coat
  * 3 Breed status
  * 4 Health
  * 5 Usage
  * 6 References
    * 6.1 Citations
    * 6.2 Bibliography

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

The Goldendoodle was first bred by [Monica Dickens](/wiki/Monica_Dickens
"Monica Dickens") in 1969.[1] Popularity for the goldendoodle grew in the
1990s[2] when breeders in North America and Australia began crossing Golden
Retrievers with Standard Poodles.[3] The original purpose of the cross was to
develop guide dogs suitable for visually impaired individuals with allergies.
Poodles are considered to be [hypoallergenic](/wiki/Hypoallergenic
"Hypoallergenic"). Their coats do not shed, which reduces
[dander](/wiki/Dander "Dander").[4] Dander is a protein that sheds from the
skin and causes allergies in humans.

The goldendoodle is referred to as a [designer dog](/wiki/Designer_dog
"Designer dog"). The [Encyclopædia
Britannica](/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica "Encyclopædia Britannica")
traces the term "designer dog" to the late 20th century when breeders began to
cross purebred [Poodles](/wiki/Poodle "Poodle") with other purebred breeds in
order to obtain a dog with the poodle's non-shedding coat, along with various
desirable characteristics from other breeds.[5] In regards to goldendoodles,
golden retrievers are considered a great family dog,[6] which is why they have
been used to cross breed with poodles.

## Appearance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Appearance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/2770692200812301939581Goldendoodle_pup_7_weeks_old.jpg/220px-2770692200812301939581Goldendoodle_pup_7_weeks_old.jpg)](/wiki/File:2770692200812301939581Goldendoodle_pup_7_weeks_old.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2770692200812301939581Goldendoodle_pup_7_weeks_old.jpg
"Enlarge")

Goldendoodle puppy at 6 weeks old--the coat starts out quite flat and becomes
more curly as the puppy grows older

### Shedding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Shedding")]

Although not all goldendoodles exhibit the hypoallergenic coat type of the
[Standard Poodle](/wiki/Standard_Poodle "Standard Poodle"), most goldendoodles
do have a low to non-shedding coat.[3] While the degree of shedding varies
from dog to dog, overall, the goldendoodle exhibits less shedding than other
dogs. Grooming requirements include regular brushing, occasional bathing and
some fur trimming. Due to minimal shedding, Goldendoodles tend to have less
[dander](/wiki/Dander "Dander"), reducing allergic responses.[7]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Finnegan_the_Goldendoodle_having_fun_in_the_snow.jpg/220px-
Finnegan_the_Goldendoodle_having_fun_in_the_snow.jpg)](/wiki/File:Finnegan_the_Goldendoodle_having_fun_in_the_snow.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Finnegan_the_Goldendoodle_having_fun_in_the_snow.jpg "Enlarge")

1 Year-old Goldendoodle with medium length hair

### Coat[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Coat")]

There are three main coat types. There is the straight coat, which is flat and
resembles more of a golden retriever coat. The wavy coat type is a mixture of
a poodle's curls, and a golden retriever's straighter coat. The last coat type
is curly, which tends to look more like the poodle coat. A goldendoodle's size
is generally somewhere between that of its poodle parent and golden retriever
parent. The ranges of size include standard, medium, and miniature (if the
poodle parent was miniature). Upon reaching adulthood, a standard goldendoodle
will often weigh 60 to 100 pounds. A medium goldendoodle will weigh between 30
and 45 pounds and a miniature goldendoodle will weigh approximately 15 to 30
pounds. The standard in height at the shoulder for a male goldendoodle is
about 24-26 inches. For females, it is 22-23 inches. Often, taller
goldendoodles inherit more from the golden retriever and will weigh
substantially more. It is very common for the goldendoodle to inherit the
"golden retriever bump" on top of his/her head.[3][8] Common coat colors
include white, cream, apricot, gold, red, and sometimes gray and black (also
called phantom). Goldendoodles may also be black or a light sandy brown.[9]
They are classified into types according to the breed of its parents. An F1
goldendoodle is the offspring of a poodle mated with a golden retriever. An
F1B goldendoodle is the offspring of a poodle with an F1 goldendoodle.[10] An
F2 goldendoodle is the offspring of an F1 and another F1 goldendoodle, and an
F2B goldendoodle is the offspring of an F1 and an F1B goldendoodles.

## Breed status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Breed status")]

See also: [Selective breeding](/wiki/Selective_breeding "Selective breeding")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/3100489919_06e44ec1da_Goldendoodles.jpg/220px-3100489919_06e44ec1da_Goldendoodles.jpg)](/wiki/File:3100489919_06e44ec1da_Goldendoodles.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:3100489919_06e44ec1da_Goldendoodles.jpg "Enlarge")

Golden retriever and her litter of goldendoodle puppies, after having mated
with a poodle.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Twelve-
week_old_goldendoodle_pup.JPG/220px-Twelve-
week_old_goldendoodle_pup.JPG)](/wiki/File:Twelve-
week_old_goldendoodle_pup.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Twelve-week_old_goldendoodle_pup.JPG "Enlarge")

Twelve-week-old Goldendoodle puppy

Some breeders prefer to restrict breeding to the first generation (F1) and
first generation cross-back (F1B).[7] This is done in an attempt to maximize
genetic diversity and avoid the inherited health problems that have plagued
many dog breeds.[10]

Established breed associations such as the [AKC](/wiki/American_Kennel_Club
"American Kennel Club"), the [UKC](/wiki/United_Kennel_Club "United Kennel
Club"), and the [CKC](/wiki/Canadian_Kennel_Club "Canadian Kennel Club"), do
not recognize this hybrid, nor any other designer cross, as a breed. However,
some major kennel clubs do accept registration of crossbreed and mixed-breed
dogs for performance events such as agility and obedience such as the
Continental Kennel Club. The Continental Kennel Club will accept and grant a
pedigree on a goldendoodle as long as the parents have registration.

## Health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Health")]

With knowledgeable breeding, the goldendoodle tends to be a rather healthy
dog, but Poodles and Golden Retrievers are both susceptible to [hip
dysplasia](/wiki/Hip_dysplasia_\(canine\) "Hip dysplasia \(canine\)").
Therefore, an [OFA](/wiki/Orthopedic_Foundation_for_Animals "Orthopedic
Foundation for Animals") or [PennHIP](/wiki/PennHIP "PennHIP") exam is highly
recommended to check for this problem before dogs are bred.

Both breeds can also suffer from a number of inheritable eye disorders, so it
is important that annual CERF (Canine Eye Registration Foundation) exams are
performed before breeding.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The goldendoodle inherits the ears of Golden
Retrievers; because their ears hang and do not allow water to drain, they are
prone to ear infections and yeast infections in the ears from swimming. [Von
Willebrands disease](/wiki/Von_Willebrands_disease "Von Willebrands disease")
(vWD), a bleeding disorder, can also be found in the Poodle and should be
screened through DNA tests before breeding.

## Usage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Goldendoodle&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Usage")]

Since 2005, Goldendoodles have been used as pets, agility dogs, [guide
dogs](/wiki/Guide_dog "Guide dog"), [therapy dogs](/wiki/Therapy_dog "Therapy
dog"), diabetic dogs, [search dogs and rescue
dogs](/wiki/Search_and_rescue_dog "Search and rescue dog"), as they have
inherited the poodle's intelligence and the golden retriever's ease of
training.[11] Goldendoodles have also become increasingly used as domestic
pets due to their affection towards families, as well as their friendliness
and patience with children and strangers.[12]

"Edit section: References")]

qa.question: what kind of dog is a golden doodle
qa.answer: ['a cross-breed dog, which is obtained by breeding a Golden Retriever with a Poodle']
